isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: Pu-erh tea and theabrownin ameliorate metabolic syndrome in mice via potential microbiota-gut-liver-brain interactions
studies.description: Metabolic syndrome (MS) is a common metabolic disorder characterized by obesity, insulin resistance, cardiovascular disease and gut microbiota dysbiosis. Pu-erh tea and its ingredient theabrownin have known functions on the reduction of body weight gain and fat accumulation. However, few studies systematicly analyze the different contributions and mechanisms of their anti-metabolic syndrome functions through multi-omics combination analysis. Here, we used metagenomics, transcriptomics and metabolomics technology to investigate the anti-metabolic syndrome mechanism of Pu-erh tea and theabrownin in MS mice. Our results suggested that Pu-erh tea and theabrownin interventions could improve the physiological functions of liver, jejunum and adipose tissues in MS mice. Hepatic transcriptome revealed that both interventions could regulate the circadian rhythm pathway. Glycerophospholipid and linoleic acid metabolism were also modulated by both interventions through serum and brain metabolome analysis. Faecal metagenome demonstrated that both interventions could increase the relative abundance of Clostridiales bacterium 42_27, Blautia coccoides and Firmicutes bacterium ASF500, but decrease the relative abundance of Brevundimonas vesicularis. Otherwise, compared with Pu-erh tea, theabrownin markedly upregulated the levels of hepatic antioxidants (i.e., SOD, GSH), prominently downregulated hepatic inflammatory factors (i.e., IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α) and malondialdehyde oxidant, but modestly reduced obesity-associated short-chain fatty acids in faeces in MS mice. Taken together, our data provided insights into the homogeneous and heterogeneous natural biological functions of theabrownin and Pu-erh tea in the treatment of metabolic syndrome.

publications.title: Pu-erh tea and theabrownin ameliorate metabolic syndrome in mice via potential microbiota-gut-liver-brain interactions
publications.authorList: Hou Yan, Zhang Zhifang, Cui Yinshan, Peng Chunxiu, Fan Yanqun, Tan Chao, Wang Qiuping, Liu Zhipeng, Gong Jiashun

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Preparation of Pu-erh tea and extraction of theabrownin:

Fermented Pu-erh tea was obtained from Meng Hai Tea Factory (Catalogue No. 7262–1801, 2018, Xishuangbanna, Yunnan, China). Theabrownin (TB), the major extract from Pu-erh tea, was prepared according to our previous studies[1]. Briefly, Pu-erh tea was ground into powder, extracted by 10-fold volume of absolute ethanol extraction for 12 h and vacuum freeze-dried[2]. The residue was extracted with a 10-fold volume of boiled distilled water, continuously stirred at 85 °C for 20 min followed by filtration under vacuum, and extracted 3 times. Then, the extracts were combined and concentrated to 1/5th of the total volume by vacuum evaporation. The concentrated solution was extracted by chloroform, ethyl acetate, and n-butanol 2, 3, and 4 times, respectively. The aqueous layers were evaporated and precipitated to obtain crude theabrownin extracts using absolute ethanol[2].


The Sevage method was performed to further purify the extracted crude theabrownin and deproteinize. The purified theabrownin was collected and deproteinized for use, and the content of theabrownin was 68.50%, as determined using a previous method with slight modification[3]. In addition, other components of the crude extracts were also measured as follows: 4.75% amino acid, 13.08% polysaccharide, 2.34% total catechin, and 0.15% theaflavin, which have been reported in our previous study[4]. Metformin hydrochloride tablets (H20023371, Bristol Myers Squibb Co., ltd., Shanghai, China) were used as the test drug.


Animals and experimental design:

The experimental procedures involving animals were carried out according to the recommendations of the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of Yunnan Agricultural University (approval number 202203021). Specific-pathogen-free (SPF) db/db (MS mice) and db/m (control mice) male mice (8 weeks old) were purchased from Changzhou Cavins Laboratory Animal Co., ltd. (licence number: SCXK (Su) 2016–0010). All of the mice were maintained under SPF conditions in an environmentally controlled room with a 12 h light/dark cycle at 20-22 °C and a relative humidity of 55-65%. All mice had free access to food and fresh water throughout the experiments.


After 1 wk of acclimation, the mice were randomly divided into 8 groups: group K (db/m mice), group KE (db/m mice + Pu-erh tea), group KB (db/m mice + theabrownin), group KY (db/m mice + metformin), group MS (db/db mice group), group ME (db/db mice + Pu-erh tea), group MB (db/db mice + theabrownin), and group MY (db/db mice + metformin) with 10 mice in each group. Pu-erh tea (2 g/kg body weight), theabrownin (TB) (1.215 g/kg body weight) and metformin (0.524 g/kg body weight) were given by gavage orally once daily according to the body weight as previously described[4][5]. The experiment lasted 12 wk, and all mice were fed a normal diet for the first 8 wk followed by 4 wk of a high-fat diet (30% lard and 1% cholesterol). During the experiment, the activity of the mice was observed every day, while food and water consumption, as well as body weight were recorded weekly.


After 12 wk, blood samples were collected from the eyeball after fasting overnight and kept at room temperature for 1 h to ensure complete clotting. Serum was obtained by centrifugation at 3,000 rpm for 15 min at 4 °C and stored at −80 °C for metabolomics analysis. Brain tissues were carefully excised after the mice were euthanized. Tissues were washed with normal saline, weighed and immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen. The visceral index (organ weight/body weight, mg/g) was calculated. All tissues were stored at −80 °C until analysis.


Refs:

[1] Hou Y, Shao W, Xiao R, Xu K, Ma Z, Johnstone BH, Du Y. Pu-erh tea aqueous extracts lower atherosclerotic risk factors in a rat hyperlipidemia model. Exp Gerontol. 2009 Jun-Jul;44(6-7):434-9. doi:10.1016/j.exger.2009.03.007. PMID:19348878.

[2] Huang F, Zheng X, Ma X, Jiang R, Zhou W, Zhou S, Zhang Y, Lei S, Wang S, Kuang J, Han X, Wei M, You Y, Li M, Li Y, Liang D, Liu J, Chen T, Yan C, Wei R, Rajani C, Shen C, Xie G, Bian Z, Li H, Zhao A, Jia W. Theabrownin from Pu-erh tea attenuates hypercholesterolemia via modulation of gut microbiota and bile acid metabolism. Nat Commun. 2019 Oct 31;10(1):4971. doi:10.1038/s41467-019-12896-x. PMID:31672964.

[3] Wang Q, Gong J, Chisti Y, Sirisansaneeyakul S. Bioconversion of tea polyphenols to bioactive theabrownins by Aspergillus fumigatus. Biotechnol Lett. 2014 Dec;36(12):2515-22. doi:10.1007/s10529-014-1632-0. PMID:25214210.

[4] Lei S, Zhang Z, Xie G, Zha C, Miao Y, Chen D et al. (2022). Theabrownin modulates the gut microbiome and serum metabolome in aging mice induced by D-galactose. Journal of Functional Foods, 89, 104941. doi:10.1016/j.jff.2022.104941.

[5] Yue SJ, Liu J, Gong JS. Effects of Theabrownin Extracted from Pu-erh Tea on the Intestinal Flora[J]. Journal of Tea Science, 2016, 36(3): 261-267.

doi: 10.13305/j.cnki.jts.2016.03.005

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
The collected serum and brain samples were processed on ice, and the extraction procedure was conducted according to the method described in previous studies with modification[1][2]. Briefly, 50 μl of serum sample was added to 150 μl methanol (containing 1 μg/ml L-2-chlorophenylalanine). After vortexing, the samples were sonicated for 10 min in an ice-water bath to obtain a stock solution. A 50 mg brain sample extracted with 10 ml extract solution (acetonitrile:methanol:water = 1:1:1, containing 1 μg/ml L-2-chlorophenylalanine) was used for the stock solution preparation. Then, all the stock solutions were incubated at −40 °C for 1 h and centrifuged at 12,000 rpm for 15 min at 4 °C to obtain the supernatant. Samples for quality control (QC) were prepared by mixing with an equal aliquot of the supernatants from all serum or brain samples.


Refs:

[1] Dunn WB, Broadhurst D, Begley P, Zelena E, Francis-McIntyre S, Anderson N, Brown M, Knowles JD, Halsall A, Haselden JN, Nicholls AW, Wilson ID, Kell DB, Goodacre R; Human Serum Metabolome (HUSERMET) Consortium. Procedures for large-scale metabolic profiling of serum and plasma using gas chromatography and liquid chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry. Nat Protoc. 2011 Jun 30;6(7):1060-83. doi:10.1038/nprot.2011.335. PMID:21720319.

[2] Want EJ, Masson P, Michopoulos F, Wilson ID, Theodoridis G, Plumb RS, Shockcor J, Loftus N, Holmes E, Nicholson JK. Global metabolic profiling of animal and human tissues via UPLC-MS. Nat Protoc. 2013 Jan;8(1):17-32. doi:10.1038/nprot.2012.135. PMID:23222455.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description: The LC-MS/MS was performed using a UHPLC system (Vanquish, Thermo Fisher Scientific) with a UPLC BEH Amide column (2.1 mm x 100 mm, 1.7 μm, Waters) coupled to a Q Exactive HFX mass spectrometer (Orbitrap MS, Thermo). The mobile phase consisted of 25 mmol/L ammonium acetate and 25 mmol/L ammonia hydroxide in water (pH = 9.75) (A) and acetonitrile (B). In total, 3 μl of diluent was applied to the column, and the analysis was performed using an elution gradient as follows: 0–0.5 min, 95% B; 0.5–7.0 min, 95-65% B; 7.0–8.0 min, 65-40% B; 8.0–9.0 min, 40% B; 9.0–9.1 min, 40-95% B; and 9.1–12.0 min, 95% B. The column temperature was 25 °C. The autosampler temperature was 4 °C.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: A QE HFX mass spectrometer was used to acquire MS/MS spectra in information-dependent acquisition (IDA) mode. The ESI source conditions were set as follows: sheath gas flow rate of 50 Arb, Aux gas flow rate of 10 Arb, capillary temperature of 320 °C, full MS resolution of 60000, MS/MS resolution of 7500, collision energy of 10/30/60 in NCE mode, and spray voltage of 3.5 kV (positive) or −3.2 kV (negative).

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
The acquired MS data pretreatments included peak selection and grouping, retention time correction, second peak grouping, and isotopes and adducts annotation, which were performed as previously described with a few modifications[1]. LC–MS raw data files were converted into mzXML format and then analysed using the XCMS[2] and CAMERA[3] toolbox with R software.


Refs:

[1] Liu R, Hong J, Xu X, Feng Q, Zhang D, Gu Y, Shi J, Zhao S, Liu W, Wang X et al. Gut microbiome and serum metabolome alterations in obesity and after weight-loss intervention. Nat Med. 2017 Jul;23(7):859-868. doi:10.1038/nm.4358. PMID:28628112.

[2] Tautenhahn R, Böttcher C, Neumann S. Highly sensitive feature detection for high resolution LC/MS. BMC Bioinformatics. 2008 Nov 28;9:504. doi:10.1186/1471-2105-9-504. PMID:19040729.

[3] Kuhl C, Tautenhahn R, Böttcher C, Larson TR, Neumann S. CAMERA: an integrated strategy for compound spectra extraction and annotation of liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry data sets. Anal Chem. 2012 Jan 3;84(1):283-9. doi:10.1021/ac202450g. PMID:22111785.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
Metabolites were identified using the online HMDB database[1] and KEGG database[2] or LipidBlast database[3] using exact molecular mass data (m/z) from significant peaks. If a mass difference between observed and theoretical mass was < 10 ppm, the metabolite was annotated, and the molecular formulas of the matched metabolites were further identified and validated by isotopic distribution measurements. Commercial reference standards were used to validate and confirm metabolites by comparing their MS/MS spectra and retention time.


Statistical and correlation analysis:

The significant difference between the treatments was determined by Fisher’s least significant difference (LSD) test using SPSS 20.0 (IBM SPSS, USA) with the significance criteria set as P-value < 0.05.


Multivariate predictive modelling of each omics dataset was conducted using partial least square-discriminant analysis incorporated into a repeated double cross-validations framework (rdcv-PLS) with ‘mixOmics’ (v6.8.5)[4] in R. Spearman’s rank correlation analysis between differentially expressed gut bacteria, metabolites, gene and cytokine factors was also performed with R (v 3.6.2).


The relative s.d. (RSD) value of metabolites in the QC samples was set at a threshold of 30% as a standard in the assessment of repeatability in metabolomics datasets. The Mann-Whitney-Wilcoxon test was carried out to determine the significance of each metabolite. PCA and orthogonal partial least-squares discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA) were conducted with R. Metabolomics Pathway Analysis (MetPA) was performed with a hypergeometric test for overrepresentation analysis and relative-between centrality for pathway topology analysis by the online tool MetaboAnalyst (v4.0).


Refs:

[1] Wishart DS, Jewison T, Guo AC, Wilson M, Knox C, Liu Y, Djoumbou Y, Mandal R, Aziat F et al. HMDB 3.0--The Human Metabolome Database in 2013. Nucleic Acids Res. 2013 Jan;41(Database issue):D801-7. doi:10.1093/nar/gks1065. PMID:23161693.

[2] Kanehisa M, Goto S. KEGG: kyoto encyclopedia of genes and genomes. Nucleic Acids Res. 2000 Jan 1;28(1):27-30. doi:10.1093/nar/28.1.27. PMID:10592173.

[3] Rohart F, Gautier B, Singh A, Lê Cao KA. mixOmics: An R package for 'omics feature selection and multiple data integration. PLoS Comput Biol. 2017 Nov 3;13(11):e1005752. doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005752. PMID:29099853.

[4] Wang Y, Kuang Z, Yu X, Ruhn KA, Kubo M, Hooper LV. The intestinal microbiota regulates body composition through NFIL3 and the circadian clock. Science. 2017 Sep 1;357(6354):912-916. doi:10.1126/science.aan0677. PMID:28860383.
